first_reading.text:
[[Is 55,6]]Seek the LORD while he may be found, call him while he is near.
[[Is 55,7]]Let the scoundrel forsake his way, and the wicked man his thoughts; Let him turn to the LORD for mercy; to our God, who is generous in forgiving.
[[Is 55,8]]For my thoughts are not your thoughts, nor are your ways my ways, says the LORD.
[[Is 55,9]]As high as the heavens are above the earth, so high are my ways above your ways and my thoughts above your thoughts.
first_reading.title: Book of Isaiah

psalm.text:
[[Ps 145,2]]Every day will I bless you, 
and I will praise your name forever and ever.
[[Ps 145,3]]Great is the LORD and highly to be praised; 
His greatness is unsearchable.

[[Ps 145,8]]The LORD is gracious and merciful,
slow to anger and of great kindness.
[[Ps 145,9]]The LORD is good to all 
and compassionate toward all his works.

[[Ps 145,17]]The LORD is just in all his ways 
and holy in all his works.
[[Ps 145,18]]The LORD is near to all who call upon him, 
to all who call upon him in truth.
psalm.title: Psalms

second_reading.text:
[[Ph 1,20c]]Brothers and sisters: Christ will be magnified in my body, whether by life or by death.
[[Ph 1,21]]For to me life is Christ, and death is gain.
[[Ph 1,22]]If I go on living in the flesh, that means fruitful labor for me. And I do not know which I shall choose.
[[Ph 1,23]]I am caught between the two. I long to depart this life and be with Christ, (for) that is far better.
[[Ph 1,24]]Yet that I remain (in) the flesh is more necessary for your benefit.
[[Ph 1,27a]]Only, conduct yourselves in a way worthy of the gospel of Christ.
second_reading.title: Letter to the Philippians

gospel.text:
[[Mt 20,1]]Jesus told his disciples this parable: "The kingdom of heaven is like a landowner who went out at dawn to hire laborers for his vineyard.
[[Mt 20,2]]After agreeing with them for the usual daily wage, he sent them into his vineyard.
[[Mt 20,3]]Going out about nine o'clock, he saw others standing idle in the marketplace,
[[Mt 20,4]]and he said to them, 'You too go into my vineyard, and I will give you what is just.'
[[Mt 20,5]]So they went off. (And) he went out again around noon, and around three o'clock, and did likewise.
[[Mt 20,6]]Going out about five o'clock, he found others standing around, and said to them, 'Why do you stand here idle all day?'
[[Mt 20,7]]They answered, 'Because no one has hired us.' He said to them, 'You too go into my vineyard.'
[[Mt 20,8]]When it was evening the owner of the vineyard said to his foreman, 'Summon the laborers and give them their pay, beginning with the last and ending with the first.'
[[Mt 20,9]]When those who had started about five o'clock came, each received the usual daily wage.
[[Mt 20,10]]So when the first came, they thought that they would receive more, but each of them also got the usual wage.
[[Mt 20,11]]And on receiving it they grumbled against the landowner,
[[Mt 20,12]]saying, 'These last ones worked only one hour, and you have made them equal to us, who bore the day's burden and the heat.'
[[Mt 20,13]]He said to one of them in reply, 'My friend, I am not cheating you. Did you not agree with me for the usual daily wage?
[[Mt 20,14]]Take what is yours and go. What if I wish to give this last one the same as you?
[[Mt 20,15]](Or) am I not free to do as I wish with my own money? Are you envious because I am generous?'
[[Mt 20,16a]]Thus, the last will be first, and the first will be last."
gospel.title: Holy Gospel of Jesus Christ according to Saint Matthew
